column2: officially the City of Dipolog (Cebuano: Dakbayan sa Dipolog; Subanen: Gembagel G'benwa Dipuleg/Bagbenwa Dipuleg; Chavacano: Ciudad de Dipolog)
column3: is a 3rd class city and capital of the province of Zamboanga del Norte
column4: Philippines. According to the 2015 census
column5: it has a population of 130
column6: 759 people.Geographically
column7: the city is surrounded by rolling hills to the southeast and the Sulu Sea to the north. Dipolog is known for its wild orchids and its sardine industry which stems from the rich fishing area off its shores. It is known as the "Gateway to Western Mindanao" through the Western Nautical Highway

column1: and has also been called the "Bottled Sardines Capital of the Philippines."Dipolog can be reached by plane via Dipolog Airport or by ferry at the nearby Pulauan Port
in Dapitan City. The construction of a roll-on/roll-off facility at Barangay Galas will allow for the eventual transfer of the service to Dipolog while retaining inter-island operations at Pulauan
column2: which is soon to become a base port.

column1: A popular city attraction is the foreshore Dipolog Boulevard which
column2: though still in its second phase of construction
column3: has become a popular haven for exercise and leisure. It is also the site for various celebrations and festivals in the city. In the third phase of the project
column4: the length of the boulevard will be extended to reach the seaport in Barangay Galas.

column1: Dipolog City is known to be as the "Gateway to Western Mindanao" it is situated in the Northwestern part of the Province of Zamboanga del Norte. It is bounded on the north by Dapitan City
column2: on the east by the Municipality of Polanco
column3: on the south by the Municipality of Sergio Osmeña Sr. and on the west by the Municipality of Katipunan.

column1: Its land area in 1914 covered an approximate land area of 248
column2: 587 hectares under Act No. 302 of the Philippine Islands. It was substantially reduced in 1951 to the current 13
column3: 628 hectares
column4: after two barrios of Dipolog were converted into Municipalities of Polanco
column5: and Piñan under Executive Order of the President No. 467
column6: dated August 22

column1: Dipolog City is politically subdivided into 21 barangays.
Dipolog has a tropical rainforest climate
column2: according to the Köppen Climate classification with ample rain distributed quite evenly throughout the year and warm to hot temperatures. The city experiences a wetter period from June to December
column3: with June
column4: October and November being especially wet.

column1: Earliest recorded political history of Dipolog started in 1834 with the re-organization of Spanish Provincial Government of Misamis. At that time
column2: Tulwanan's political territory was still part of the Municipality of Dapitan with Don Domingo Ruiz
column3: a native
column4: as its capitán or town executive.

column2: a Spanish Recollect missionary arrived in Tulwanan looking for its barrio executive or local chieftain. Upon meeting a native
column3: the missionary asked; "¿Dónde está el capitán?" or "Where is the captain?". The native understanding only the word "capitán" pointed to the west and said in Subanen Di-pag
column4: meaning across the river. Guided by his servant
column5: a Tagalog boy named Antonio Subido
column6: the missionary proceeded down river and upon reaching the Boholano settlement

column2: Dipag and Tulwanan were two different settlements at that time with the former composed of Boholano natives and the latter mostly of Subanen ancestry. When the friar returned to Dapitan
column3: he identified the location of the larger Boholano settlement as Dipag but was not officially written. Frequent conversations by the Spaniards pronounced it in Spanish accent Dipolog which was eventually adopted by the natives. The final political survey surprisingly added the letter 'L' written on it after officially becoming a barrio of Dapitan. From that time Tulwanan's political identity ceased to exist.

column1: By the 12th century the Subanen settlers had colonized most of what is now Zamboanga Peninsula region. It was customary for tribes to establish their settlements at the mouth of large river systems due to the abundant food supply. However
column2: due to frequent raids from seafaring Chinese pirates
column3: they decided to move their settlements inland.

column2: Tulwanan was established 6 kilometers inland
column3: adjoining the river near the present day barangay center of Lugdungan.

column2: settlers from neighboring Negros and Bohol islands established coastline settlements in Mindanao but suffered the same raids by Chinese pirates
column3: prompting them to also move their settlements away from the coastline. They established another settlement in what is now called Sianib
column4: a barangay of present-day Polanco town
column5: some twenty kilometers from the coast at Barrio Gulayon(Barangay Gulayon).

column1: It was only in 1563 that the first recorded Visayan settlement of some 800 families from Bohol
column2: led by the chieftain Datu Pagbuaya
column3: landed in Mindanao and established a coastal settlement in what is now called Dapitan. This settlement was strong enough to repel the Chinese pirates of the Sulu Sea. As a result
column4: Dapitan Bay was scene of many bloody conflicts between Pagbuaya's men and Chinese pirates.

column2: Don Miguel López de Legazpi who was accompanied by famed navigator Fr. Andrés de Urdaneta
column3: an Augustinian friar
column4: visited the Boholano chieftain Datu Pagbuaya on the invitation of Datu Sikatuna. There they found the place of Datu Pagbuaya to be a thriving settlement. In his chronicle
column5: Fr. Urdaneta named the place Daquepitan. Peter Kaerius (Pieter van den Keere) identified the location as Dapito in his cartographic map of 1598. It was later identified as "Dapite" in Robert Dudley's map of 1646. Other names ascribed to the location include "Dapyto" in Sanson's map of 1652 and "Dapitan" which can be found in Moll's map of the East Indies
column6: 1729 and in Murillo Velarde's map of 1734. After Legazpi's visit
column7: the Christianization of Mindanao was officially initiated by the Augustinian friars who arrived with him.

column2: members of The Society of Jesus came to the Philippines for the purpose of evangelization. When the country was divided among four religious orders in 1598
column3: the Jesuits were given the Diocese of Cebu which covered the Visayas and Mindanao. Thus Dapitan came to be under the jurisdiction of the courageous men of St. Ignatius and it was Father Pascual de Acuña S.J. who started the Jesuit mission there.

column2: the squadron of Juan Juarez Gallinato S.J. defeated the Manguindanau Muslims in a ferocious battle near Dapitan.Also in 1609
column3: a permanent Dapitan mission was founded and thereafter headed by a Jesuit missionary
column4: Father Pedro Gutierrez
column5: marking Dapitan as the Center of Evangelization in Mindanao. Mission stations were subsequently established later by the Jesuits in Zamboanga
column6: Iligan
column7: Basilan and Butuan. Outside of these areas
column9: the whole of Mindanao remained untouched by the Spanish Cross.

column2: with the Spanish Naval Fleet anchored at Dapitan Bay
column3: much of the piracy—now conducted mainly by moro bandits—was under control within the Sulu Sea. Settlement in coastal areas resumed with new settlers from Negros and Bohol eventually settling in Isab
column4: and Nipaan. The largest settlement
column5: however
column6: was made at the mouth of the Dipolog river by the Boholanos who were not associated with Pagbuaya.

column1: After the transfer of Spanish sovereignty to the United States in 1897
column2: the U.S. occupation forces renamed the Capitan to Presidente Local
column3: with administrative support from a Vice Presidente Local

column2: Dipolog was a thriving commercial community with new settlers arriving from the island of Cebu
column3: outgrowing its principal town of Dapitan which exclusively remained part of Pagbuaya's clan.

column2: John Helper
column3: who was previously appointed Secretary of Zamboanga Province
column4: visited Dipolog for two days and conversed with its principalía and members of the Centro Catolico de Dipolog. He was asked later of the possibility of converting the community to an independent Municipality.

column2: Gov. John J. Pershing of the Department of Mindanao and Sulu decreed the separation of Dipolog from Dapitan and reorganize as a municipality again.

column1: The first public school teachers of Dipolog
column2: during this time
column3: came also from Bohol
column4: particularly Maribojoc and other towns. Most were only elementary graduates. But they were well-educated by the American soldier-teachers in Bohol. One of them was a certain Felisa Ruaya who taught at the American-established schools in Dipolog. She lived first near the beach in Punta Corro. Then she married an Adriatico

column1: === Japanese regime and World War II ===

Governor Matias Castillon Ranillo Sr. noticed that the waters at Punta Coro wharf were choppy for ships to anchor.  Governor Ranillo was determined to provide an alternative access to southern Zamboanga peninsula.  Governor Ranillo's jurisdiction was then the entire Zamboanga peninsula prior to its division between del Norte and del Sur.  During Governor Ranillo's term
column2: aviation was a young technology but he made sure that an airfield was established in Dipolog.

column1: He was elected Governor in 1937 and re-elected in 1940 but his term was cut short when Philippine President Manuel L. Quezon urged him to run as the lone Assemblyman of Zamboanga peninsula.  President Quezon fondly called him "El Gallo Escondido de Malacanang".  In November 1941
column2: he was elected as Assemblyman but one week before his scheduled departure for Manila
column3: World War II broke out. On October 30
column5: upon the request of the guerrillas
column6: he mobilized the able-bodied men of Dipolog and Home guards who cheerfully volunteered to clear the airfield of grass and shrubs.

column2: when the Japanese invaded the Philippines
column3: Zamboanga acting Governor Felipe B. Azcuna moved the capital from Zamboanga City to Dipolog. On March 8
column5: on Dipolog airfield
column6: the first American invasion of Zamboanga peninsula took place. The successful landing at Dipolog airfield established a base for the subsequent recapture of Japanese-held San Roque airfield near Zamboanga City
column7: followed by Sanga Sanga in Sulu
column8: and from there to Borneo and the East Indies. After the defeat of the American-Filipino forces in Corregidor
column9: most of the province went under Japanese control. This designation lasted until June 16
column10: 1948 when the capital was transferred from Dipolog to Molave
column11: Zamboanga del Sur through Republic Act No. 286 signed by President Elpidio Quirino.

column3: Zamboanga province is separated into two provinces of Zamboanga del Norte and Zamboanga del Sur through Republic Act 711. Dipolog became the capital of Zamboanga del Norte upon creation.On June 21
column5: through the effort of former Congressman Alberto Q. Ubay
column6: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos signed into law Republic Act 5520 or "Charter of the City of Dipolog"
column7: making Dipolog a chartered city effective January 1
column8: 1970. The date is both significant and historic as that coincided with the Apollo 11 launching which carried the first men to the moon on June 21

column1: Mayor Felicisimo Herrera was made the last Municipal Mayor (1963–1970) and the first City Mayor of Dipolog (1970–1978). On March 8

column2: a study by the National Statistics Coordination Board (NSCB) found Dipolog City to be the wealthiest city per capita in the Zamboanga Peninsula. Within Dipolog
column3: 23.15% of the population was estimated to be living below the poverty line (households with a per capita expenditure of under $1 a day). In comparison
column4: the NCSB estimated Zamboanga City and Pagadian as having poverty incidences of 23.81% and 27.15%
column5: respectively. In startling contrast
column6: the poverty rate for the entire province of Zamboanga del Norte (with individuals in both rural and urban settings) was estimated to be 40.36%. Zamboanga del Norte is one of the Philippines's poorest provinces with a poverty incidence rate of 64.6% in 2003
column7: an increase from 47% in the 2000 statistical figures.

column2: the City Hall
column3: is located at Rizal Avenue in Barangay Central. The local government structure is composed of one mayor
column4: one vice mayor and ten councilors all elected through popular vote. Two ex officio members are added to the City Council with one representing Dipolog's 21 Barangay Captains being the Association of Barangay Councils (ABC) President
column5: and one representing Dipolog's 21 Barangay Youth Council Presidents being the Sangunniang Kabataan (SK) Federation President. Each official

column1: Dipolog shared much of its cultural history with the ancient town of Dapitan to which it once belonged. It traces its beginnings long before the Spanish conquistadores set foot on the island of Mindanao. Dipolog was previously known as Tulwanan
column2: in native language
column3: literally meaning a settlement by the river. Its earliest settlers all belonged to the Subanen Tribe called Subanon or river people with established religion founded in animism. These descended from the Austronesian peoples who roamed Mindanao and Southeast Asia via land bridges as early as 30
column4: 000 years ago Later migrations of other tribes were made by water and took place over several thousand years.

column2: sikads (bicycle-powered tricycles)

column1: Santa Cruz - The tall cross stands at Punta Corro
column2: the spot where migrating Boholanos landed and to establish a settlement. The cross was erected by the settlers on Roodmas

The town cathedral was later built in 1894 to replace the old church. Dr. José Rizal designed the high altar from a sketch requested by his former professor and former curé of Dipolog
